Detailed Description

TeleoReactor abstract interface.

This class provides the basic framework for a Teleo-Reactor as defined for the TREX architecture. A Teleo-reactor (or reactor) is the basic construct managed by a TREX agent.

It is the also the node of a transaction graph connected with other reactors through the timeline relations it have with them. These relations can be deduced from how a reactor declares the timelines it manipulate:

  • External timelines is a state variable provided by another reactor in the graph. The reactor can observe its evolution and -- even though it cannot directly control this timelien value -- it can potentially post goals on this timeline expressing desired future value(s).
  • Internal timelines is a state varaible managed by this reactor and made publicly available in the graph. It is the repsonsibility of this reactor to provide new Observation when the value of this timeline change. Similarly this reactor will receive goals posted by other reactors that declared this timline as External

A reactor provide also informations about its latency and look-ahead which indicates its planning horizon and the maximum time it is exx1pected to deliberate in order to produce a plan for the goals it received.

All these informations are used by the agent in order to schedule the communication between agents along with their deliberation.

Author:
Conor McGann & Frederic Py <fpy@mbari.org>
See also:
class graph

typedef xml_factory::argument_type TREX::transaction::TeleoReactor::xml_arg_type

XML construction info.

The argument passed by xml_factory while calling reactor classes constructor. This type is not a simple rapidxml::xml_node<> but also embeds a reference to the graph that the newly created instance will be attached to.

Constructor & Destructor Documentation

TeleoReactor::TeleoReactor ( TeleoReactor::xml_arg_type &  arg,
bool  loadTL = true,
bool  log_default = true 
) [explicit]

XML based constructor.

Parameters:
[in] arg A structure embedding the xml structure and the graph that called this constructor
[in] loadTL A flag to allow/prohibit the parsing of Internal and External relations gfrom the xml structure
[in] log_default A flag to indicate what is the default logging behavior for this reactor

This constructor creates a new reactor by parsing the xml structure arg. Ig loadTL is true it will also extract Internal and External timelines definitions from this structure. log_default indicates what is the default logging behaivor of the reactor when the log attribute is not given in the XML structure.

A typical reactor definition is as follow 

 < <RType> name="<name>" lookahead="<lookahead>" latency="<latency>"
           config="<config>" log="<logflag>" >
      <External name="<ename>" goals="<post goal flag>" />
      <Internal name="<iname>" />
 </ <RType> >

With :

  • <RType> being the type of the reactor as declared to the factory
  • <name> the name of the reactor
  • <lookahead> the reactor's look-ahead
  • <latency> the reactors's latency
  • <logflag> a flag use to indicate that observations and commands issued from this reactor should be logged or not (default is log_default)
  • <config> An optional extra file that extends the defintions of this tag

If loadTL is true then that class will also parse the External and Internal tags in order to declare internal and external timelines of this reactor.

Exceptions:
TREX::utils::XmlError An error occured while extracting reactors information from the XML structure

Definition at line 446 of file TeleoReactor.hh.

TeleoReactor::size_type TeleoReactor::count_internal_relations (  )  const

Count the number of internal relations.

This method count the number of relations that this reactor have with other reactors issued from its internla timelines.

This number does not count the number of internal timelines but the sum of all the reactors that are connected to this reactor through its internal timelines

bool TeleoReactor::doSynchronize (  ) 

Synchronization callback.

This method is called by the agent to make the reactor execute its synchronization. It will call synchronize callback and returns then status of the reactor according to the execution of this call.

Return values:
true synchronization successfull
false the call to synchronize returned false or thew an exception
Warning:
when this method returns false this reflect a critical reactor failure. Therefre the agent will kill this reactor and produce the observation Failed on each of its Internal timeline.
See also:
synchronize()

TREX::utils::Symbol const& TREX::transaction::TeleoReactor::getAgentName (  )  const [inline]

get "agent" name

Gets the name of the agent that controls this reactor.

Deprecated:
reactors are now manipulated by a graph. The agent uses this graph to trigger reactor's callbacks based on graph traversal algorithms. A graph is a more general concept thatn an agent (for example a graph could allow to have cyclic dependencies between reactors ...) to reflect this change this method has been replaced by getGraphName() and kept for backward compatibility.
Returns:
the name of the "agent"
See also:
getGraphName() const

TICK TREX::transaction::TeleoReactor::getExecLatency (  )  const [inline]

reactor execution latency

Indicates the reactor execution latency. This value correspond to the delay it take s for thsi reactor to start executing its plan. It is function of the execution latency of the reactors it depends on and is updated automatically by the reactors graph.

This value is used by TREX and represent this reactor's dispatch window lowe bound.

Returns:
the reactor's execution latency
See also:
getLatency() const

virtual void TREX::transaction::TeleoReactor::handleInit (  )  [inline, protected, virtual]

reactor initialiszation callback

This callback is called during initialize() is order to allow derived classes to complete their initialization before the reactor goat executed.

It is called once at the beginning of the reactor ewxecution.

Bug:
this function is blocking and while it is usuaally called before the clock of the agent got started if the reactor is created at the beginning of the mission. it won't be the case for a reactor created on the fly which may be problematic if the calls takes too long in comparison of the tick duration.

Reimplemented in TREX::europa::EuropaReactor.

virtual void TREX::transaction::TeleoReactor::handleTickStart (  )  [inline, protected, virtual]

New tick callback.

This call back is executed at the beginning of a new tick. and can be used for the reactor to prepare for synchronization. It is also often used by the reactor to post its new goals.

Note:
at this stage the reactor should have received all the new goals for this tick. but this is not guaranteed.
Warning:
the duration of this call should be neglectable in comparison to the tick duration.

Reimplemented in TREX::europa::EuropaReactor.

Definition at line 717 of file TeleoReactor.hh.

Referenced by newTick().

virtual bool TREX::transaction::TeleoReactor::hasWork (  )  [inline, protected, virtual]

Check if need to deliberate.

This method is called during workRatio in order to idenitfy if the reactor needs to deliberate.

By default it always return 0 and need to be redefined by derived classes if they need to deliberate.

Return values:
true this instance needs to deliberate
false this instance does not require deliberation

If the methods returns true this will eventually result on the agent calling the step() method

See also:
workRatio()
step()

Reimplemented in TREX::europa::EuropaReactor.

Definition at line 546 of file TeleoReactor.hh.

Referenced by workRatio().

bool TeleoReactor::initialize ( TICK  final  ) 

Final initialization.

Parameters:
[in] final The final tick date
Precondition:
getCurrentTick() < final
the reactor has not been inited yet

This method is called by the agent to allow the reactor to complete its initialization. At this stage the treactor knwos that it is part of the reactor graph and can complete its initialisation if needed. During this call, the callback handleInit will be executed allowing to execute reactors spacific initializations

Exceptions:
ReactorException Attempted to call this method twice
Postcondition:
The reactor is ready to be executed in the agent
See also:
handleInit()
getInitialTick() const
getCurrentTick() const

New tick notification callback.

This method is called by the agent to notify the reactor that a new tick has started. It will call the handleTickStart() method

virtual void TREX::transaction::TeleoReactor::notify ( Observation const &  obs  )  [inline, virtual]

New observation callback

Parameters:
[in] obs An observation

This method is called by the agent when one of the External timelines of this reactor changed state. The state is described by obs and satrts from the current tick.

It is guartanteed that all the notification of the current tick will be notified before the reactor synchronization

Warning:
the duration of this call should be neglectable in comparison to the tick duration.
See also:
synchronize()

Reimplemented in TREX::europa::EuropaReactor.

Definition at line 368 of file TeleoReactor.cc.

References postGoal().

Here is the call graph for this function:

bool TeleoReactor::postGoal ( goal_id const &  g  )  [protected]

Post a goal.

Parameters:
[in] g A goal id

Post the goal g to an external timeline

Precondition:
g is a valid goal_id (i.e. not NULL)
g->object() is an External timeline of this reactor
Exceptions:
DispatchError The goal was not valid or was not on an external timeline of this reactor
Returns:
true the goal has been succesfully posted and is queued for dispatching
false this goal id is already in the dispatching queue
Note:
sucessfully posting a goal do not gauarantee that this goal will be duispatched and even less executed. It can be already too late to dispatch such a goal or the goal is simply impossible to be executed in current situation. As of today, the only way to check a goal has been executed is to wait for the corresponding observation unitl the maximum start time has been passed.
See also:
isExternal(TREX::utils::Symbol const &) const

void TeleoReactor::postObservation ( Observation const &  o  )  [protected]

Produce an observation.

Parameters:
[in] o An observation

This method is a falcility to produce internally an observation o on one of the reactors Internal timeline.

It can be called internally to the reactor when a new state has been identified for this timeline.

Precondition:
o.object() is internal to this reactor
Postcondition:
Unless postObservation is called in between with an observation on the same object, the observation o will be dispatched to all the clients of o.object() during the next doNotify()
Exceptions:
SynchronizationError attempt to post an observation in a timeline which is not Internal to this reactor.
See also:
class Observation
isInternal(TREX::utils::Symbol const &) const
doNotify()

Post a planned token.

Parameters:

Inform that the token g is now part of the plan of the reactor

Precondition:
g is a valid goal_id (i.e. not NULL)
g->object() is an Internal timeline of this reactor
Exceptions:
DispatchError The token was not valid or was not on an internal timeline of this reactor

false this token id is already broadcasted or its end time is in the past

bool TeleoReactor::postRecall ( goal_id const &  g  )  [protected]

Recall a goal.

Parameters:
[in] g A goal

This method recall the goal with the goal_id of g

Return values:
true the goal was sucessfully recalled
false the goal was not valid or is not on an External timeline
Note:
The goal_id g should be execatly the one passed to postGoal (or returned by it).
As for postGoal sucessfully recalling a goal does not mean that it will be removed from the plan of the owner of this timeline. It is more a way to indicate that this goal is not required anymore.
See also:
postGoal(goal_id const &)
postGoal(Goal const &)

void TeleoReactor::provide ( TREX::utils::Symbol const &  timeline,
bool  controllable = true,
bool  publish = false 
) [protected]

Internal timeline declaration.

Parameters:
[in] timeline a name
[in] controlable does this timeline accept goals
[in] publish does this timeline will publish its plan

This method is used to declare timeline as an Internal timeline.

Warning:
The type of a timeline can change during reactor execution and this is the reason why this methods give no feedback. It is always recommend to check the success/failure of this operation using isInternal
Note:
If the timlien was External and is not woned yet by any reactor, this call will promote it as Internal

virtual void TREX::transaction::TeleoReactor::resume (  )  [inline, protected, virtual]

Deliberation step callback.

This callback will be executed in response of hasWork returning true. It allows the reactor to execute an atomic deliberation step.

Warning:
the duration of this call should be neglectable in comparison to the tick duration.

Reimplemented in TREX::europa::EuropaReactor.

void TeleoReactor::step (  ) 

Deliberation step.

This method is aclled by the agent when it allows the reactor to do one deliberation step. It calls resume() and update informations in order to compute the reactors next work ratio

virtual bool TREX::transaction::TeleoReactor::synchronize (  )  [protected, pure virtual]

Synchronization callback.

This method is called in order to ask for the reactor to

  • resolve its current state
  • produce new observation on its exeternal timelines if their state have changed The agent ensures that all new observation on this reactor timelines have been produced -- and received through notify -- to this reactor.

This is one of the more critical callback of the reactor and when it fails is considereed as a critical error resulting on the resactor being killed by the agent

Return values:
true synchronization succeeded
false synchronization failure. Will result on the reactor being killed soon after
Warning:
the duration of this call should be neglectable in comparison to the tick duration.

Implemented in TREX::europa::EuropaReactor.

Referenced by doSynchronize().

double TREX::transaction::TeleoReactor::tickToTime ( TICK  cur  )  const [inline]

tick to unix time conversion

Parameters:
[in] cur A tick value
Returns:
equivalent unix time to cur as a float

This method is an utility to ease the conversion form a tick to unix time it calls the agent clock corresponding method to convert the specified tick value into unix time

Note:
the result of the method depends on the clock implementation. For example the RealTimeClock fully support it while the StepClock will simply assume that unixtime and tick are perfeclty aligned (as if the mission started on January 1st 1970)

void TeleoReactor::use ( TREX::utils::Symbol const &  timeline,
bool  control = true,
bool  plan_listen = false 
) [protected]

External timeline declaration.

Parameters:
[in] timeline a name
[in] control goal dispatching flag
[in] plan_listen plan listening flag

This method is used to declare timeline as an External timeline. The optional control flag prohibits goal dispatching to this timeline when false. The plan_listen flag aloow the reactor to be notified whenever the owner of this timeline does give the current tokens it has in his future plan

Precondition:
The timleine is not already Internal
Warning:
The type of a timeline can change during reactor execution and this is the reason why this methods give no feedback. It is always recommend to check the success/failure of this operation using isExternal

double TeleoReactor::workRatio (  ) 

reactor deliberation work load

This method calls hasWork method and, depending on the returned value and how close the reactor is to reach is latency, will give a value indicating heurisitically how urgent it is for him to delinerate.

Returns:
a value that becomes larger as the reactor is approaching its latency deadline or NAN if hasWork() returned false
See also:
hasWork()
step()
